comments.commentBody:
To M Beck:
"Switch to terrorism"? Wouldn't be much of a switch.
Yes, it does read like a movie. Add one John Travolta & stir well

Persons like yourself could do society a great favor by applying your skills to prosecute Wall Street's criminal activities. Or perhaps you could investigate some of the crimes committed by our politicians. Because frankly, those of you engaged in drug interdiction seem to be as big opportunists as those you persue. Trust me, you're not fooling anyone.

Nr
The pro pot people here are demonstrating what's wrong with recreational pot smoking. Not one of these people leaving comments questioning the incarceration of Jimmy Cournoyer was able to absorb any of the facts in the article that made it clear as can be that he is a career criminal who knows no boundaries and should be denied the opportunity to do things like maintain a $2 million murder fund and facilitate the importation of cocaine into Canada which is certainly not part of a peace and love subculture.

.. a chicken in every pot and pot in every pocket...thx Colorado for voting smart.
though no longer partake of chicken or of pot,, articles as such drive the drive the need for > legalization.
The US has the NSA. 300 of the world's best number theory mathematicians. Just like the Chinese.

Whenever I hear the sure-as-election-year-clockwork appeals to 'Save (what's left of) the Middle Class', I'm reminded of a political cartoon from the 1940 presidential campaign. It's captioned 'Campaign Baby of the Year', and the rather unhappy-looking baby being kissed by both President Franklin D. Roosevelt and his GOP challenger Wendell Willkie is labeled 'Peace'. Substitute 'Middle Class Americans' and you've got the idea. But unlike that very horrible year, this time the candidates do have some way to help that baby. The question is, do they - and their corporate supporters, who've been given a 'free' pass to export our jobs to China and India (among other lands), have any inclination to do so? Even though the present arrangement, for lack of a better word, has led to lost jobs resulting in a gradually dying market for their products? Not to mention high-tech goodies manufactured in a country that actually has a 'Cyber Army' division, consisting of uniformed personnel, stationed at an office complex in Shanghai, busily working on computers at all hours? Hackers, perhaps? Or, more likely in my humble (?) opinion, busily crafting all sorts of nice malware?
Maybe Frank Zappa had it right from the get-go: "Scientists consider hydrogen to be the building block of the universe, but I disagree. I'm convinced that the real building block is stupidity. It's the only thing that's in infinite supply."
DVA- you must be posting from Moscow- you spelled "Luhansk" -"Lugansk"- one is Ukrainian the other Russian- you used the Russian spelling.. more fake American people commenting here- again...

I agree, it is good to bring an end to the bloodshed. The Ukrainian people, whether ethnic Russians or not, need to be allowed to return to a normal way of life.... no matter who is governing them. However, it is very bad for Ukraine as a sovereign nation. Putin knows now that he can just take whatever he wishes with little resistance from the rest of the world. If he wished to take all of Ukraine in the future, it is his for the taking.

So how is the whole Crimea thing working out now.... I read that the economy has tanked and things aren't nearly as nice as it was under Ukrainian rule. I guess eastern Ukraine can look forward to such an impoverished Russian rule.

Even western Ukraine will eventually feel these consequences, as their economy continues to tank. They had such high hopes to one day have a thriving economy such as Poland's. Oh well, Putin obviously knows best, as the West and NATO has conceded.

It would almost be laughable if it weren't for the fact that it is completely so dishonorable and devastating for Ukraine and the Ukrainian citizens, including those Russian ethnic ones.
You need to expand your sources beyond RT.

Putin has been and is the "Real" threat- he just proved it... 12 years of deceit on his part- faking that he wanted peaceful coexistence then suckering the EU with his supply of nat gas and supposed "free market" in Russia.. the West is guilty of being caught flat footed- duped by a smooth talking KGB officer.
You are correct, princeton08540. I've reported it, and a correction will be issued. In the meantime, we've corrected the puzzle in the online version and the archive.
This is like when we do our addresses in Excel and they don't format the field correctly - all New Englanders get cheated out of their initial zero!
I believe that 26D is misclued. It should have read Luke 23:40, not 23:4. Perhaps the two have the same value in a spreadsheet; not in the bible.
I think the "regular" people of Ukraine overwhelmingly elected Poroshenko knowing exactly that he was going to do what he said.
Well, 2,600 dead people might have a problem seeing Putin's "compassion."

You guys are right in that Russia didn't need to annex Crimea. It didn't. It was presented with a golden opportunity and it took the opportunity. Any way you slice it, Judy is right that the future of Russia's base is secure, and much more secure than sharing space with Ukraine, and much much more secure than dealing with a NATO allied Ukraine, as Ukraine was surely leaning. It replaced the uncertainty of dealing with a fairly hostile government in Kiev with what? Even the pundits at the time had to admit that the referendum was overwhelming and would have gone in Russia's favor with or without the voting irregularities. It was a no-brainer for Russia and you guys know it.

You should probably separate this out with the war going on in the east right now, though. Apples and oranges.

@CliffM
You can't understand that offering an amnesty if they do so isn't the same thing as demanding their surrender, especially given the political concessions in the offer? One does not offer decentralization and safe conduct to negotiators in a surrender demand, the offer is simply that those who do lay down their arms will not be prosecuted.

Is Biletskiy's comment really that horrific? The thrust of the article is that Putin would only offer ceasefire terms that were to his own benefit. It's just a game, a ceasefire is not a milestone in this conflict, it's just another hammer in Putin's arsenal of weapons for asymmetric warfare. To negotiate with invading Russian troops and foreign mercenaries is like asking a thief to please put down the television, while politely ignoring the fact that he's not going to leave, but will stay inside your houes until he has the chance to steal something else.

Poroshenko would do well to strike a liberal deal with the East.  In terms of his political survival, he very well may have more to fear from his own militias -- and Mr. Kolomoiski -- than he does from his restive Russophone population.

A decentralised government is what Russia has been insisting upon all along. It keeps Ukraine fractured and destabilised. Puppet Governors put up by Russia allows them to retain influence. This has all been a carefully thought out and strategized plan on the part of Putin and other KGB Hawks. A plan that has used time and again in other former Soviet controlled states. There cannot be any security or stability if Russia is allowed to get away with this. The Crimea situation remains unacceptable and should not be permitted. It is a certainty that any plans to join the E.C, NATO or anything else will be blocked or frustrated.

Putin has been consistently attacked by Russian hardliners for not going far enough.  You've really grabbed the wrong end of the stick with this idea that Russia "scoffed at his bold plan."  That's not at all the way Russian national sentiment has run.

I do not mean to say that the majority of Russians do not strongly support his actions. I mean to say that far-right Russia consistently wanted more, and some did not believe Putin had the intestinal fortitude to deliver this kind of victory in the face of Western pressures. He proved them wrong.

This is a terrible harbinger of things to come in more than one way. It portends the lack of courage the West has when a totalitarian dictatorship would illegally seize the sovereign territory of a recognized nation state; secondly it posits the unavoidable conclusion that Putin, now completely emboldened, will try this gambit on many other borders, including the islands of the North Pacific.

Mark my words: Putin has proven his domestic naysayers wrong. They scoffed at his bold plan. Now that we have not answered Putin with equal force, he knows that he can get away with these theiving land-grabs any time, any where, and in whatever way he wants.

His slimy plan worked. We would be brain-dead not to expect that he will apply the same template to other borders.

What's your point? That whenever Putin has a "national interest" we all run away to find a way to appease his "national interests?" Utterly naive and dangerous, to say the least. Does not the ukraine have national interests? Does not the Ukraine have sovereignty? What happened to the Treaty of Westphalia?
I hope the cease fire holds and turns into a lasting peace for the people ther--and also to confound  the jingoists who have been commenting about this event so vociferously and erroneously.

Ukraine will lose the eastern part of its' sovereign nation as the world watches and allows it to happen.  But this is Poroshenko's only viable option outside of full war with Russia.  It is the only way now to stop the bloodshed and allow the people to move forward with their lives.  True Ukrainians will have to move westward into Ukraine or be subject to Russian rule and serious condemnation and torture because they are Ukrainian.  Funny how we never heard of such things against the ethnic Russians in Ukrainian territory before all of this, but now is a common practice in Crimea.   Also ironic that Crimean people are suffering much more now under a Russian rule than they were under the Ukrainian rule.  I guess they got what they wanted..... or so the Russian media portrays.  I think an honest poll of Crimean people would prove otherwise.
Utterly absurd. Our president would bolster defenses against illegal totalitarian land-grabs, and you quote extreme right Rove/Palin talking points.

I thank Eva Moskowitz for taking up the bathroom issue years ago.  As a mother of a public school kindergartener who wet her pants the second week of school because all of the toilets in the school restroom were overflowing and lacking toilet paper, I moved my daughter to Success Academy and have never had to worry about the bathrooms since. No child should have to worry about not having a flushable toilet to use. The disgusting bathrooms in NYC Public Schools need to be a top issue again.

Argument number one is that when you separate the most motivated students from the rest you damage the education of the less motivated ones.  Damaging someones education is not a crime but it should be.
